diagnoses: Viral infections such as infectious mononucleosis
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Connective tissue diseases (e.g., Systemic lupus erythematosus)
Viral infections (e.g., Herpes simplex virus, Epstein-Barr virus)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Urinary Tract Infection (UTI) with associated Rash
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) with associated UTI
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Viral Infections (e.g., Epstein-Barr Virus, Human Immunodeficiency Virus)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reason: This autoimmune disease can present with widespread symptoms, including acute pericarditis, seizures (as a result of CNS involvement), arthropathy, and cutaneous manifestations such as dyspigmentation.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reason: Although primarily known for its impact on joints causing arthropathy and synovitis, in severe cases or during flare-ups, systemic symptoms can include pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Another autoimmune condition, Sjögren's Syndrome could theoretically cause arthropathy and has been associated with neurological manifestations that might include seizures. Skin manifestations can occasionally include dyspigmentation.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reason: This multisystem inflammatory disease can cause acute pericarditis, seizures (neurosarcoidosis), arthropathy, and skin changes including dyspigmentation.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.reason: An autoimmune disorder characterized by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash can also involve joint problems (arthropathy) and has been linked with cardiological and neurological manifestations, including pericarditis and, although rare, seizures.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.reason: This disease features signs and symptoms of a combination of disorders including lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis and can present with pericarditis, seizures, arthropathy, and skin changes.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.reason: This rare disorder causes blood vessel inflammation throughout your body and can lead to acute symptoms such as skin changes (including dyspigmentation), arthritis, and, less commonly, seizures.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: An autoimmune disorder often associated with lupus, it can cause a variety of symptoms including those affecting the skin, neurological symptoms such as seizures, joint symptoms, and cardiological involvement which can include pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.reason: Though primarily affecting the heart valves, when severe, it can manifest as pericarditis, and it can also cause a variety of systemic effects including arthropathy, skin manifestations (including petechiae that might be misinterpreted as dyspigmentation), and in rare cases, seizures.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.reason: Caused by the Borrelia burgdorferi bacterium, Lyme disease can cause arthritis (especially in the knees), heart problems including pericarditis, and neuroborreliosis, which can present with seizures. Skin manifestations early in the disease include erythema migrans, a kind of dyspigmentation.

diagnoses: Schizophrenia with concurrent autoimmune or infectious condition

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. It can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, potentially leading to follicular hyperkeratosis, leukopenia, psychosis, delirium, and proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Pellagra
diagnoses.description: A deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3) or its precursor tryptophan. Symptoms include dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia (which can manifest as psychosis and delirium), and in severe cases, proteinuria due to kidney damage.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the kidneys caused by systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), resulting in proteinuria. Neuropsychiatric symptoms can include psychosis and delirium; leukopenia is also common in SLE.

diagnoses.name: Porphyria
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders caused by abnormalities in the chemical steps leading to the production of heme. Symptoms can include skin issues (possibly follicular hyperkeratosis), psychosis, and in certain types, proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Schizophrenia
diagnoses.description: A serious mental disorder characterized by distortions in thinking, perception, emotions, language, sense of self, and behavior. While rare, in severe cases, psychotic episodes might be accompanied by physical symptoms like leukopenia due to antipsychotic medication side effects.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus/Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome. It can cause a wide array of symptoms including leukopenia (due to the virus attacking immune cells), proteinuria (from kidney damage), and neuropsychiatric disorders such as psychosis and delirium.

diagnoses.name: Scurvy
diagnoses.description: A disease resulting from a deficiency in vitamin C. It can cause a range of symptoms including follicular hyperkeratosis. While psychosis and delirium are less common, they can appear in severe cases alongside general malaise.

diagnoses.name: Kwashiorkor
diagnoses.description: A form of severe protein malnutrition characterized by edema, an enlarged liver with fatty infiltrates, and skin conditions like follicular hyperkeratosis. Neurological impairment can also occur, including delirium in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Hepatic Encephalopathy
diagnoses.description: A decline in brain function that occurs as a result of severe liver disease. In this condition, the liver cannot adequately remove toxins from the blood, leading to symptoms like delirium and potentially proteinuria if kidney function is affected.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that forms in plasma cells, which are a type of white blood cell made in the bone marrow. It can cause proteinuria due to kidney damage, and in rare cases, neurological symptoms such as delirium and psychosis may occur.

diagnoses: Viral infections (e.g., Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, HIV)
Hepatitis B or C (with associated cryoglobulinemia)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's Syndrome
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) with concomitant physical health issues

diagnoses.description: An anxiety disorder characterized by recurrent unexpected panic attacks, including symptoms like palpitations, pounding heart, or accelerated heart rate, and fear of losing control.
A rare, genetic disorder causing recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema), typically affecting the limbs, face, intestinal tract, and airway.
A disorder characterized by chronic, exaggerated worry and tension that is unfounded or much more severe than the normal anxiety most people experience.
A condition where the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormone, leading to symptoms like fatigue, dry skin, and sometimes angioedema.
An autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and tissue damage throughout the body, including skin rash, arthritis, and kidney involvement. It can also cause pallor and dysmenorrhea.
A common type of anemia that occurs when the body lacks sufficient iron to produce healthy red blood cells, leading to pallor among other symptoms.

A rare autoimmune disease that can cause swelling and damage to blood vessels (arteries), potentially affecting any organ but often impacting skin, nerves, and muscles, possibly leading to symptoms like pallor.
A condition that affects a woman's emotions, physical health, and behavior during certain days of the menstrual cycle, generally just before her menses. It can include both dysmenorrhea and anxiety.
A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. Fatigue may worsen with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest.
A condition in which a change from lying to standing causes an abnormally large increase in heart rate, often accompanied by symptoms of anxiety, pallor, and fatigue.

diagnoses.explanation: Symptoms such as oral pain and angioedema may indicate an allergic reaction, which can also affect overall sensation and potentially lead to changes in appetite.

This rare genetic condition leads to recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema). It does not typically cause itching or hives but can lead to pain in various body parts, including the abdomen, potentially causing bloating.
Abdominal bloating, increased appetite, and oral discomfort could be symptoms of food intolerance, as the body struggles to digest certain foods.

IBS can cause bloating and is often associated with a change in appetite. While not directly linked to oral pain or vulvodynia, the discomfort and stress associated with IBS may exacerbate these conditions.
This autoimmune disorder, triggered by gluten, can cause a wide range of symptoms beyond typical gastrointestinal issues, such as bloating and oral ulcers, which could be perceived as oral pain.

This chronic condition can cause painful patches inside the mouth, contributing to oral pain. It's not directly linked to the other symptoms but could accompany systemic issues affecting various body parts.
PMS can lead to bloating, changes in appetite, and even affect sensitivity to pain, which might make conditions like vulvodynia more noticeable.
PCOS may present with increased appetite and bloating among its symptoms. The hormonal imbalances associated with PCOS can potentially exacerbate or lead to the onset of vulvodynia.
Increased appetite could signify an underlying eating disorder, which also might cause bloating and oral health issues due to nutritional deficiencies.
Stress and anxiety can have physical manifestations that exacerbate or mimic symptoms of pain, bloating, and changes in appetite, affecting overall sensitivity and pain perception.

diagnoses.rationale: ITP can lead to easy bleeding due to low platelet count, and individuals might also experience other symptoms, though warts are not directly associated.
Chronic kidney failure can cause hypertension and vomiting. Metabolic imbalances may lead to various systemic symptoms, though not specifically warts.
This condition might cause hypertension and easy bleeding due to increased blood viscosity and volume. It doesn't typically present with warts.
Can lead to chronic fatigue (potentially mistaking chronic back pain), vomiting, and in severe cases, heavier or irregular periods that might seem like easy bleeding. Warts are not a direct symptom.
May cause hypertension, and easy bruising. Chronic back pain can result from osteoporosis, which is a complication of Cushing's.
This bleeding disorder can lead to easy bleeding. It does not directly cause hypertension, warts, or chronic back pain.
Directly responsible for the development of warts. Some strains might be associated with conditions that present with symptoms of easy bleeding though typically not hypertension or chronic back pain.
This condition can cause multiple symptoms including chronic pain and in advanced stages might affect the liver, leading to vomiting. It doesn't directly cause hypertension.
Can lead to vomiting and easy bleeding. Hypertension might be secondary to chronic pain or other factors. Warts are not associated.
A type of blood cancer that could cause back pain due to bone lesions, easy bleeding, and through kidney damage might induce hypertension. Warts are not a symptom.

diagnoses: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (for infertility in women)

diagnoses.name: Behçet's disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disorder affecting multiple parts of the body, including the eyes, mouth, skin, and genitals. Symptoms often include mouth ulcers, genital ulcers, eye inflammation, and can include various skin lesions.
diagnoses.treatment: Treatment aims at reducing symptoms and preventing complications, involving medications like corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, and anti-TNF agents.

diagnoses.name: Reiter's syndrome (Reactive arthritis)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune condition that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body. It is characterized by arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis in men (inflammation of the urethra) or cervicitis in women (inflammation of the cervix).
diagnoses.treatment: Management involves antibiotics if a bacterial infection is still present, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and sometimes immunosuppressive medications.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands responsible for keeping the eyes, mouth, and other parts of the body moist. Primary symptoms include dry eyes and dry mouth.
diagnoses.treatment: Focuses on relieving symptoms, with artificial tears, saliva stimulants, and immunosuppressive drugs.

diagnoses.name: Crohn's disease
diagnoses.description: A type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from mouth to anus. Symptoms can range from abdominal pain, diarrhea, weight loss, to complications outside the GI tract such as skin rashes and arthritis.
diagnoses.treatment: There's no cure, but treatment options include anti-inflammatory drugs, immune system suppressors, antibiotics, and surgery.

diagnoses.name: Celiac disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. Symptoms include diarrhea, weight loss, and malabsorption.
diagnoses.treatment: The only effective treatment is a strict gluten-free diet for life.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A virus that attacks the immune system. If left untreated, it can lead to the disease AIDS. Symptoms in early stages can be flu-like, progressing over time to more severe complications like weight loss, fever, diarrhoea, and opportunistic infections.
diagnoses.treatment: While no cure exists, antiretroviral therapy (ART) can dramatically prolong the lives of many people infected with HIV and lower their chance of infecting others.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis (TB)
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs but can also impact other parts of the body. Symptoms include a bad cough that lasts 3 weeks or longer, weight loss, fatigue, fever, night sweats, and chills.
diagnoses.treatment: A long course of antibiotics, typically for 6 to 9 months.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by flares and remissions and can affect the joints, skin, brain, lungs, kidneys, and blood vessels.
diagnoses.treatment: No cure exists, but treatments include anti-inflammatory medications, immune suppressants, and steroids.

diagnoses.name: Lichen sclerosus
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes thin, white, patchy skin, usually in the genital and anal areas. It can cause itching, pain, and scarring.
diagnoses.treatment: Treatment often involves potent topical steroids to reduce inflammation and itching.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. The first sign is usually a round, firm, painless sore on the genitals or rectum. The disease can progress to more severe stages if not treated.
diagnoses.treatment: Antibiotics, primarily penicillin, are very effective in treating syphilis in its early stages.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that can lead to laryngeal edema, vomiting, and skin reactions such as pruritus. Syncope and incontinence may occur due to the sudden decrease in blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Acute Intermittent Porphyria
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder causing abdominal pain, vomiting, and neurological complaints including incontinence and possibly syncope, with some patients experiencing pruritus due to skin sensitivity.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition where mast cells release too much of their content, leading to a wide range of symptoms including pruritus, vomiting, syncope, and potentially laryngeal edema.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A genetic condition causing episodes of edema in various parts of the body including the larynx, which may lead to laryngeal edema, and can also cause abdominal pain resulting in vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the adrenal glands leading to insufficient production of certain hormones, which can cause symptoms like vomiting, abdominal pain, and orthostatic hypotension that could lead to syncope.

diagnoses.name: Neurocardiogenic Syncope
diagnoses.description: A condition that leads to fainting as a response to a trigger, such as intense emotional stress or pain, and may be associated with preceding nausea or vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.description: A rare tumor of the adrenal gland tissue causing episodes of high blood pressure, headaches, vomiting, and potentially syncope due to dramatic shifts in blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Vasovagal Syncope
diagnoses.description: A common cause of fainting episodes triggered by certain stressful or unpleasant stimuli, possibly preceded by nausea or vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Shock Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain bacterial infections, characterized by sudden high fever, vomiting, diarrhea, rash, and possibly leading to syncope and multi-organ failure.

diagnoses.name: Cholinergic Urticaria
diagnoses.description: A form of chronic hives that is related to the body's release of acetylcholine, a chemical in the body's nervous system, causing symptoms like pruritus, vomiting, and potentially syncope if severe.

diagnoses: Allergic reaction to food or medication
Acute urinary retention with overflow incontinence

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden numbness, weakness, especially on one side of the body, confusion, trouble speaking, understanding speech, and severe headache.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief period of symptoms similar to those in a stroke. A TIA usually lasts only a few minutes and doesn't cause permanent damage. Symptoms are similar to those of strokes but resolve within minutes to hours.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines are a type of headache characterized by intense pain along with nausea and sensitivity to light and sound. An aura is a group of sensory, motor or verbal disturbances that signal the onset of a migraine. Symptoms include visual disturbances (scintillation), speech difficulties (aphasia), and numbness or weakness.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral Aneurysm
diagnoses.description: A cerebral aneurysm is a weak bulging spot on the wall of a brain artery. Over time, the blood flow within the artery hammers at the thinned portion of the wall, potentially leading to a rupture. Before rupture, it may cause symptoms like headache, numbness, weakness, or difficulty with vision and speech.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Depending on the tumor's location, it could cause various neurological symptoms, including headaches, speech problems, numbness or weakness on one side of the body, and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis is a chronic illness of the central nervous system. This disease damages the myelin sheath, the material that surrounds and protects your nerve cells. This damage slows down or blocks messages between your brain and body, leading to symptoms such as numbness, weakness, balance issues, and trouble speaking.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: Epilepsy is a central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Some types of epilepsy are associated with specific symptoms including aphasia and sensory disturbances including scintillation.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain, usually from a bacterial or fungal infection. Symptoms might include headache, fever, weakness, seizures, and problems with speech and vision.

Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain caused by a viral infection or, in rare cases, a bacterial infection. It can lead to symptoms including headache, fever, confusion, stiff neck, seizures, problems with movement or sensation, and speech or hearing problems.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an infection of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord (meninges). It's usually caused by a viral or bacterial infection and can lead to symptoms such as severe headache, fever, stiff neck, confusion, aversion to bright light, and seizures. In severe cases, it may cause problems with memory, concentration, and speech.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms like weakness and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain, which can cause symptoms such as nausea, weakness, and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms, including severe headaches, nausea, and sometimes speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves, potentially leading to weakness and speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack (TIA) produces stroke-like symptoms but usually has no lasting effects.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known as the meninges, which can lead to symptoms such as weakness and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, often caused by an infection, which can lead to problems with speech, weakness, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain.

diagnoses.name: Brain abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in the brain due to an infection, which can cause symptoms like aphasia and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder where the body's immune system attacks the nerves, leading to weakness that can escalate to paralysis, and can sometimes lead to speech disturbances.

diagnoses: Raynaud's Phenomenon (associated with connective tissue diseases)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.details: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause pericarditis, skin rashes, hemolytic anemia, and nasal ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disorder that can lead to pericarditis and skin complications, though nasal ulcers and hemolytic anemia are less common.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.details: A bacterial infection of the heart valves which can occasionally lead to pericardial effusion and hemolytic anemia, with skin manifestations possible.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disease with features of lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including rashes and potentially pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.details: An inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs, including the skin, heart (with pericarditis), and potentially leading to hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.details: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, leading to skin rashes and ulcers in the mouth and nasal area.

diagnoses.name: Cryoglobulinemia
diagnoses.details: A condition associated with hepatitis C and certain autoimmune diseases, leading to skin rashes, joint pain, and can affect the kidneys.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.details: Certain types of lymphoma can present with skin rashes, hemolytic anemia, and effusions in the body cavities including the pericardial space.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.details: A bacterial infection that can cause pericarditis and possibly mimic some of the other symptoms indirectly.

diagnoses.name: Wegener's Granulomatosis (Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disease that causes vasculitis, which can lead to skin rashes, nasal ulcers, and occasionally pericardial effusions.
